text: when I was growing up we used to eat
crispy tacos all the time now I have a
tendency to eat the soft kind but every
once in a while when I'm on a nostalgic
kick I go for the crispy tacos I'm
making my own shells you could buy
shells but to start off with let's just
say we're gonna fry our own take some
corn tortillas put them in 350-degree
oil 5 or 10 seconds per side 1 2 3 4 5
and then fold them in half and hold them
in the oil in the shape that you want
them to end up this is the shape you
want
be really careful holding half of the
tortilla in the oil to get nice and
crisp for about 15 seconds make sure
that you keep the two sides apart
otherwise they'll be no place for your
filling turn it over second side cook
the other side and then drain it on some
paper towels you want them nice and
crispy and crunchy it is a little time
consuming you can make them ahead too if
you want very carefully move your oil
someplace else to cool and then you need
a large skillet to cook your taco
mixture in and I'm just gonna bring
these up to the front for later the
filling is really easy onion just needs
to be minced really really fine this
here onion is hurting my eyes Oh cruel
world a cup of onion minced three cloves
of garlic I suppose in honor of my 70s
upbringing I should be using my garlic
press for this but I'm not product of
the 70s that's right I'm old that's it
I'm done no more hard work involved
everything else piece of cake all right
I'm gonna cook my onions and garlic
until they're translucent in a
tablespoon of olive oil
now don't burn it coz there's not too

softens alright let that alone for a sec
I need a third of a cup tomato paste six

then add four teaspoons of chili powder

but I like the spice stir that around

before it burns add a pound of ground

up with the back your spoon until it's

let's get some salt in here you can
